item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: xanrin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Vagrant
item.dc:creator: xanrin
item.content:encoded:
What is Vagrant?

Vagrant is a tool that allows the system engineers to create machine configurations on their local pc, test those configurations and then push them over to the live server when the configurations are working like they should. The big advantage is that when the configuration is finished and they need some tests to run on for example 10 Amazon servers, then they just use the configured vagrant box and create those servers automatically, the script will then create the amazon server, run the tests that they need and then break the servers down again. A good advantage of runnings tests like this is that it will use the seconds as optimal as possible so that you are able to run your tests as simple and cheap as possible. Another advantage is that you can use those vagrant boxes for the developers, the developers are then able to develop on a production like environment so that the code that they wrote will 99% of the time work on the production server so eliminating a lot of errors.

Requirements

  • Vagrant:  http://downloads.vagrantup.com/
  • VirtualBox: https://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Downloads

To get started with Vagrant

  1. Open up a console and enter: 
    vagrant init
    this will create a Vagrant file in the cwd (Current Working Directory)
  2. Now you can configure your Vagrant file for your machine to install, example of a working Vagrant file is posted below.
  3. Once you are done configuring your Vagrant file just enter: 
    vagrant up
    and it will start your box
  4. Now as soon as your box booted you can enter your box in ssh by entering 
    vagrant ssh
    this will enter your SSH and you are ready to go.

Problems that i encountered

  • Windows requires a LOT more configurating, one of the problems that i encountered is that you need  to use a good Terminal, the standard command prompt is simply not good enough since you need to do  SSH connections, i used PUTTY to connect to my ssh and i also had to configure my connection key in putty because else i simply could not connect.
  • When you use a x64 box  then your computer has to support VT-x or AMD-X, this is virtualization software to make the machine run faster, if you do not have this the VM will simply not boot.

VagrantFile that i wrote

# Configurations
domain      = 'local.com' # Domain
puppetManifest = 'site.pp'

# Website Dedicated (Ubuntu Precise 12.04 LTS x86)
# x86 Since VirtualBox does not support x64 with hardware acceleration)
# To get a x64, run a production server or enable VT-x for the CPU (BIOS Settings)
# Configure the nodes, default ram = 256
nodes = [
    { :hostname => 'website', :ip => '192.168.0.2', :box => 'precise32', :url => 'http://files.vagrantup.com/precise32.box', :ram => 512 }
]

Vagrant.configure("2") do |config|
    nodes.each do |node|
        config.vm.define node[:hostname] do |node_config|
            node_config.vm.box = node[:box]
            node_config.vm.box_url = node[:url]
            node_config.vm.hostname = node[:hostname] + '.' + domain
            node_config.vm.network :private_network, ip: node[:ip]

            memory = node[:ram] ? node[:ram] : 256;
            config.vm.provider :virtualbox do |vb|
                vb.customize [
                    'modifyvm', :id, 
                    '--name', node[:hostname],
                    '--memory', memory.to_s
                ]
            end
        end
    end

    # Add PUPPET as provisioner
    config.vm.provision :puppet do |puppet|
        puppet.manifests_path = "puppet/manifests"
        puppet.manifest_file = puppetManifest
        puppet.module_path = "puppet/modules"
    end
end

item.title: Samba Space Limit Removal
item.dc:creator: xanrin
item.content:encoded:
So i am using a Samba v4 server  and suddenly hit a point where windows kept saying that i can not copy the file over to my ubuntu server because it doesn't have enough space. Running the command: 
df -h
I got the following result: 
Filesystem      Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda2       2.7T  1.2T  1.4T  47% /
none            4.0K     0  4.0K   0% /sys/fs/cgroup
udev            1.9G  4.0K  1.9G   1% /dev
tmpfs           384M  2.7M  381M   1% /run
none            5.0M     0  5.0M   0% /run/lock
none            1.9G  148K  1.9G   1% /run/shm
none            100M   24K  100M   1% /run/user
/dev/sda1        93M  121K   93M   1% /boot/efi
This showed me that i had more then enough space available to copy my files over (Around 1.4Tb). After a few hours searching i found that Samba does not handle big files well, however we can change this by applying the following lines to our /etc/samba/smg.conf file: 
[global]
max disk size = 393216 # 3Tb

[MyShare]
block size = 4096
This fixed all my problems after restarting my samba server: 
sudo service samba4 restart

item.title: Mac Unlock .dmg Files
item.dc:creator: xanrin
item.content:encoded:
So sometimes when you copy over a .dmg file from a usb stick, windows partition or anywhere else you get the problem that it shows a little lock icon on it. To unlock this file you just have to open a terminal and enter these commands: 
 sudo chflags 0 YOURFILE
 
 sudo chmod a+rx YOURFILE

item.title: Detecting Critical Css
item.dc:creator: xanrin
item.content:encoded:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=CfmUf1_M9lI
In the video above Paul Kinlan explains how to find the critical css on web pages, critical css is the css that almost completely defines the whole page.
A lot of problems found are rendering issues that are caused by the css, this is called render blocking css and will delay the load time of your page.
You can check if your website has these problems here: https://developers.google.com/speed/pagespeed/insights/
